objectives: Understand the difference between active and passive voice
Identify the subject, verb, and object in a sentence
Learn how to change sentences from active to passive voice
Know when to use the passive voice effectively

sections.text: In the active voice, the subject of the sentence performs the action. The structure is clear and direct: Subject + Verb + Object. Most sentences we use in our daily life are in the active voice because it is simple and strong.

sections.text: In the passive voice, the subject of the sentence receives the action. The focus is on the action itself, not on who performed it. The structure is: Object + Helping Verb (be) + Past Participle (V3) of the main verb + by + Subject.

topics.title: How and When to Use Passive Voice

sections.text:
To change a sentence from active to passive voice, follow these simple steps:
1.  Identify the subject, the verb, and the object.
2.  Move the object of the active sentence to the place of the subject.
3.  Add the correct form of the auxiliary verb 'to be' (is, am, are, was, were, being, been) according to the tense and the new subject.
4.  Change the main verb to its past participle form (V3).
5.  Add the preposition 'by' and then move the subject of the active sentence to the end.

examples.label: Active (Simple Present)
examples.value: He writes a letter. (Subject: He, Verb: writes, Object: a letter)

examples.label: Passive (Simple Present)
examples.value: A letter is written by him.

examples.label: Active (Simple Past)
examples.value: She helped them. (Subject: She, Verb: helped, Object: them)

examples.label: Passive (Simple Past)
examples.value: They were helped by her.

examples.label: Active (Present Continuous)
examples.value: We are watching a movie. (Subject: We, Verb: are watching, Object: a movie)

examples.label: Passive (Present Continuous)
examples.value: A movie is being watched by us.

examples.label: Active (Present Perfect)
examples.value: They have cleaned the room. (Subject: They, Verb: have cleaned, Object: the room)

examples.label: Passive (Present Perfect)
examples.value: The room has been cleaned by them.

examples.label: Active (Future Simple)
examples.value: The teacher will teach a new lesson. (Subject: The teacher, Verb: will teach, Object: a new lesson)

examples.label: Passive (Future Simple)
examples.value: A new lesson will be taught by the teacher.

sections.text: Here are some tips on when and how to use active and passive voice:
usage_examples: Tip 1: Use the active voice most of the time. It makes your writing clear, direct, and strong. For example, "The dog chased the squirrel" is stronger than "The squirrel was chased by the dog."

Tip 2: Use the passive voice when the action is more important than the person who does the action. For example, "The road was repaired last week." (Here, the repair is more important than who repaired it).
Tip 3: Use the passive voice when the doer of the action (the agent) is unknown or unimportant. For example, "My bicycle was stolen." (We don't know who stole it).
Tip 4: The passive voice is often used in scientific reports, news reports, and formal notices to sound objective and impersonal. For example, "The water was heated to 100 degrees Celsius."
Tip 5: Remember the main structure for passive voice: Object + 'be' verb + Past Participle (V3) + 'by' + Subject.
Tip 6: Always remember to change the main verb to its third form (Past Participle) in the passive voice. For example, write -> written, eat -> eaten, break -> broken.

Tip 7: The 'by' phrase (which tells who did the action) can be left out if the doer is obvious, unknown, or unimportant. For example, "English is spoken all over the world" (instead of "...by people").
